title: 104_s446
content: The Act may be cited as the "1997 Franklin Delano Roosevelt Commemorative Coin Act". The Congress acknowledges Franklin Delano Roosevelt's significant contributions as the thirty-second President of the United States, serving from 1932 until his death in 1945. He was also the only President elected to four terms in office and served as Governor of New York and Assistant Secretary of the Navy. Roosevelt led the country through the Great Depression and served as commander in chief. Franklin Delano Roosevelt's legacy includes leading the American people through World War II, establishing Social Security, authoring "The Four Freedoms," founding the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, and being the chief architect of the United Nations. His upcoming memorial will honor his leadership alongside Washington, Jefferson, and Lincoln. The Franklin Delano Roosevelt Memorial, spanning over 7 acres in Washington, D.C., will be a tribute to one of America's greatest Presidents. It will be located between the Lincoln and Jefferson memorials and is set to open to the public in 1997. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint and issue up to 500,000 half dollar silver coins with specific specifications. The coins will weigh 12.50 grams, have a diameter of 30.61 millimeters, and contain 90% silver and 10% copper. They will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. The silver for minting will be sourced from stockpiles established under the Strategic and Critical Materials Stock Piling Act. The design of the coins is also specified. The coins minted under this Act will feature a likeness of Franklin Delano Roosevelt on the obverse side and be emblematic of the Franklin Delano Roosevelt Memorial on the reverse side. Each coin will have inscriptions including the coin's value, the year "1997", and words like "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with the Franklin Delano Roosevelt Memorial Commission. The design for the coins minted under this Act will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with the Franklin Delano Roosevelt Memorial Commission, reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee, and any additions or alterations to the design must be approved by the Commission. SEC. 6. ISSUANCE OF COINS. The coins authorized under this Act may be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities at the United States Bullion Depository at West Point. The Secretary may issue coins minted under this Act only during the period from January 1, 1997, to December 31, 1997. SEC. 7. SALE OF COINS. The coins issued under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value of the coins, plus a surcharge of $3 per coin, and the cost of designing and issuing the coins. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted at a reasonable discount as well. SEC. 8. GENERAL WAIVER OF PROCUREMENT REGULATIONS. No procurement laws apply to goods and services needed for this Act, except for equal employment opportunity laws. SEC. 9. DISTRIBUTION OF SURCHARGES. Surcharges from coin sales under this Act are split equally between the National Park Foundation and the National Park Service for the Franklin Delano Roosevelt Memorial. The Comptroller General can audit the related accounts. SEC. 10. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES. SEC. 10. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES. The Secretary must ensure minting coins won't cost the government. Coins can only be issued if payment is received, security is provided, or a guarantee of payment from a qualified institution is in place.
